text: George Kiprotich "Kip" Rono (born 4 January 1958) is a Kenyan former steeplechase runner. All-time men's best 3000m steeplechase. Alltime Athletics (2015-02-06). Retrieved on 2015-06-03.Kip Rono. Sports Reference. Retrieved on 2015-06-03. He won a gold medal in the event at the 1979 African Championships in Athletics (becoming the inaugural champion) and was the first African steeplechase winner at the 1979 IAAF World Cup. Rono ranked second fastest in the world in 1980 with a time of 8:12.0 minutes, but missed the 1980 Summer Olympics due to the boycott. He was a bronze medallist at both the Commonwealth Games and All-Africa Games in 1978, finishing behind Henry Rono. He represented his country at the World Championships in Athletics in 1983 and the Summer Olympics in 1984. ==Career== Rono first came to prominence at the age of twenty by winning bronze medals in the 3000 metres steeplechase at both the 1978 Commonwealth Games and the 1978 All-Africa Games. At both events, there was a Kenyan medal sweep led by Henry Rono and James Munyala. COMMONWEALTH GAMES MEDALLISTS - ATHLETICS (MEN). GBR Athletics. Retrieved on 2015-06-03.All-Africa Games. He did compete at the Liberty Bell Classic (Olympic Boycott Games) and while Malinowski took the steeplechase, Rono was the gold medallist in the 5000 m.Olympic Boycott Games. GBR Athletics. Retrieved on 2015-06-03. He won back-to-back steeplechase titles at the Kenyan Athletics Championships in 1983 to 1984.Kenyan Championships. GBR Athletics. Retrieved on 2015-06-03. However, upon entering top level international competitions he proved to be past his best. At the 1983 World Championships in Athletics he ranked twentieth in the semi-finals with a time of 8:33.97 minutes.Kip Rono. IAAF. Retrieved on 2015-06-03. He went out in the first round at the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics, finishing ninth in his heat with a time of 8:41.75 minutes. Athletics at the 1984 Los Angeles Summer Games: Men's 3,000 metres Steeplechase Round One. Sports Reference. Retrieved on 2015-06-03. He declined in the steeplechase thereafter. His next international appearance came at the 1988 IAAF World Cross Country Championships. There he was part of a dominant Kenyan team led by John Ngugi which took all top nine placings (bar Ethiopia's Abebe Mekonnen in fifth). Rono shared in the team gold medals for his eighth-place finish. IAAF World Cross Country Championships - 12.0km CC Men - Auckland Elleslie Date: Saturday, March 26, 1988. Athchamps (archived). Retrieved on 2015-06-03. Towards the end of his career, he focused on road running. In 1988 he was fourth at the Great Scottish Run and set a half marathon best of 1:00:52 hours to win the Semi Marathon du Lion. He was also runner-up at the Giro Podistico di Pettinengo and placed third at the AAA 10 Kilometres Championship.Kiprotich Rono. Association of Road Racing Statisticians.
